results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Birthday boy
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Andrew Gregory and Sejong Park
results.brief_description: Korea 1951 - little Manuk is playing on the streets of his village and dreaming of life at the front where his father is a soldier. He returns home to find a parcel on the doorstep and, thinking it is a birthday present, he opens it. But its contents will change his life.

results.title: Punching keys
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A biting dramatisation of the effects of the new technology in deskilling the female office workforce, alienating women from the products of their labour, and rendering them replaceable by cheaper labour overseas. Cast includes a young Gina Riley.

results.title: Here's to extremes and my journey beyond
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Kim Davis and ACMI
results.brief_description: All her life, Kim Davis believed she could do anything. And she still does, despite the efforts of society or even fate. From a line of strong women, she refuses to let anything beat her and is determined to help others.

results.title: Night's High Noon: an anti-terrain
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Created amidst Australia’s 1988 Bicentenary celebrations, ‘Night’s High Noon’ proposed a flipside to stereotyped notions of recent Australian history and identity. For Australia’s Aboriginal peoples the Bicentenary represented 200 years of dispossession from their land, cultural destruction and racial prejudice. Representations of indigenous cultures allude to the appropriation and objectification of Aboriginal peoples, their artforms and traditions, in white Australian popular culture. Truth and Meaning are similarly problematised.

Produced with the assistance of the Australian Film Commission.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Flying over mother
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Melanie Coombs and Michael James Rowland
results.brief_description:
1. Vladimir is growing up on an isolated farm somewhere on the Russian Steppes. He has been brought up on his mother’s stories of all the dangers that lie in wait for boys who misbehave and he is trying - not very successfully - to overcome his fears. But one day something happens that will change the direction of his life.
  2. Vladimir has finally reached his goal - he has trained as a cosmonaut and is circling the earth. But unfortunately his capsule has malfunctioned and things don’t look so good for him…

results.title: Olympic Games, Melbourne, Australia, 1956
results.brief_description: The 1956 Olympics warranted the Straford Brothers using their cherished stock of coloured film to capture this unique event. Original footage of the Athletics field (notably pole vaulting), swimming and diving events in the pool have been compiled by Frank years later with additional video content and a voiceover. Despite shooting some of this additional footage on his living room floor (inadvertantly including a glimpse of shagpile carpet) and such ‘special effects’ as a whiteboard marker illustrating points on a map, the documentary has a lot of interesting detail about the event; about their personal experience of it and the novelty of seeing OB Television crews in action.

results.title: Blue
results.creator_credit: Curtis Wehrfritz, Michael Pacek, Bruce McDonald and Don McKellar
results.brief_description: Canadian horror director David Cronenberg puts in an impressive performance as a bored carpert factory executive whose daily routine involves minor flirtations with his secretary and cronic masturbation in the privacy of his office. This explicit and ultimately melancholy tale of pornography and loneliness is intercut with a 1960s era stag loop called ‘The bellboy and the bored housewife’ and features the film’s star reminiscing about her experiences in the sex trade.
